text: This video is rather ambiguous.  It doesn’t define what the best a man can be is.  Yes, of course bullying and sexual harassment is wrong, everyone can agree on that.  But remember, men ought to be strong, leading, of good character, honorable in pursuing a woman, and secure in his masculinity.  Men should act a certain way because that is our purpose, our duty, the order of humanity.  To make a man’s honorable masculinity relative is to interfere with the basics of our humanity, to damage the fundamentals of human society.

Again, just look at RAINN statistics, it’ll tell you everything I’m saying is true. Most male rape victims are attacked or molested by other men. That’s not an assumption. NCVS (National Crime Victimization Survey) statistics say that only 35% of male rape victims reported one or more female attackers, meaning that 65% were attacked by other men.

@chubby.baphomet see that’s the thing, your comment shows that you think that I already don’t know that catcalling is unacceptable behavior. Why would people assume that I am a sociopathic monster who doesn’t know catcalling is rude just because of my outward gender identity? I’m fairly certain the few men who stand on street corners to call out to women are not going to change their behavior because they saw a proctor and gamble ad.

@chubby.baphomet the grown man stopped two children from wrestling. This is trying to make subliminal messaging towards parents. By teaching a young son to stop resisting, and to always capitulate to any attacker that wants to violate his family and his home, we are setting that young son up for failure through emasculation.

@168tmk i think thats the miss understanding between us, I don't think any group of people should be shamed for anything unless as a whole they are doing wrong or corrupt things (criminals & etc.). I just see it as acknowledging what you're doing that could be inconvenient to others, and then trying to fix that behavior. I don't necessarily see it as "you're horrible. Stop everything." Just that as a whole try to be better if your lacking a little and that's all. Most of what i noticed in the advert personally was the grown men interfering with bullying, which I appreciated that they shed a light on. Or that in cities women notoriously don't find it flattering to be cat called. Not that they're a bad person inherently for doing said things, just that they probably shouldn't do it.

@chubby.baphomet the interesting thing to note is, most of the bad behaviors described, especially the criminal behaviors, are more associated with men who lacked a masculine father figure and are statistically more prone to recidivism. We don’t need to create a social undercurrent against masculinity, we need to be making sure there is more of it in the family structure.

@chubby.baphomet actually, I don’t support shaming people for their body type, I think people who want to change their body composition are already aware of everything they need to know—others don’t need to be reminding them. For every, “genuinely nice,” act in this commercial, there is a pigeonholed white male on the other side of this behavior correction. This conflates gender, race, and behavior. Some women throw babies in dumpsters—but women don’t need to be talked down to as if they don’t know to not do that. Same with men. Feminists need to stop assuming that we need to be told how to not rape or assault or be rude.

@168tmk oh i agree 100%. I hope you know I'm not proud of being fat, I make fun of it as a way to live with it lol. Fat people can do better, women can do better, men can do better, everyone can. I think that's just the point though, gillette focused on men cause it's their target audience, i don't think it was meant to be a selective "fuck you" to all men out there. In the ad there's plenty of guys just being genuinely nice n stuff. I think it was all just a lead by example type of advert, i don't think it was done with malicious intent.

@monika.hutch wait so if I notice that this ad conflates gender and bad behavior, you think that makes me guilty of bad behavior?? You’re doing everything PC culture identifies as bullying toxic behavior.

@chubby.baphomet fat people do affect others. That is why airlines charge for ALL seats used, because one individual is not entitled to be in the seat the neighboring individual paid for for individual comfortable use. It would be rude to criticize the individual at fault in this scenario, but the issue is often taken up with airline customer service because it really is a problem. This is one example. When you’re holding bias against another group, its easier than when they’re conflating your own identity and bad behavior.

@168tmk well in this hypothetical scenario, fat people don't really affect other people. But if it was an add on how parents eat unhealthily and therefore feed their children the same way ( i.e. the obese children epidemic were having) I would 100% agree. Do what you want to your own body but if you are negatively affecting people around you, then there is a problem.
@mrkellywrites the conflation of gender and toxic behavior. Not complicated. If the target of the bias were race instead of gender, this commercial would have received less support.

@chubby.baphomet the message is conflating gender and toxic behavior.
